advice.message:
The user 'root' is not allowed to connect from another machine (only from the localhost).
For remote connections create a dedicated user in MySQL Command Line:
CREATE USER 'dbschema'@'%' IDENTIFIED BY 'password';
GRANT ALL PRIVILEGES ON *.* TO 'dbschema'@'%' WITH GRANT OPTION;
FLUSH PRIVILEGES;

advice.pattern: is not allowed to connect|Connection refused|Access denied for user
advice.message:
Enable remote connections in MySql server. Press 'Help' for details.
In MySql Command Line, do 'SELECT user, host FROM mysql.user' and ensure the host is '%' or the current host name.
Check the password.

advice.pattern: Network Adapter could not establish the connection|Communications link failure|Connection timed out
advice.message:
1. Check MySql to be up and running.
2. The database user, password and port should be the same as configured during installation.
3. Use 127.0.0.1 for host instead of localhost

Press the 'Help' button for further tips.

advice.pattern: Network Adapter could not establish the connection|Communications link failure|Connection timed out
advice.message:
» Enable remote access in MySql Server.
» For cloud databases, ensure the database is public accessible and the security group includes your IP
» Press the Ping button
» Make sure the Firewall does not block the communication. This could be set during installation or add a inbound rule.
Check the host value. Press the PING button to check. Further tips in Help.

It seems you are trying to connect to an older version of MySql. In this case you need also an older JDBC Driver. Please press 'Manage Drivers' and upload the MySql JDBC Driver 5.1.44 jar file. Search in web browser to find it.

The URL driver requires some parameters so MySql will handle empty dates in a proper way.
Change the URL in the JDBC driver manager to :
jdbc:mysql://<HOST>:3306/<DB>?useUnicode=true&characterEncoding=UTF8&zeroDateTimeBehavior=convertToNull

advice.pattern: Cannot add foreign key constraint|Cannot add or update a child row: a foreign key constraint fails
advice.message:
Please check the FK columns (referring and referred) to use the same data type.
Check if the values in the referring table are violating the FK (exists in the referred PK table) running this query in the SQL editor:
'SELECT * FROM referencing_tbl r WHERE not exists ( SELECT 1 from pk_tbl p where p.col=r.col)'.
Please make sure you have selected a database in the Connection Dialog.

advice.pattern: Data truncated for column|Invalid use of NULL value
advice.message:
Is possible that some column records contains empty ( NULL ) values.
You can use Relational Data Editor to list and edit them ( use a IS EMPTY filter on that column ).
From SQL Editor you can execute "SELECT col FROM table WHERE col IS NULL" and "UPDATE table SET col='value' WHERE col IS NULL".

advice.pattern: can be only one auto column and it must be defined as a key
advice.message:
Autoincrement column values are generated by the database.
It should be maximal one autoincrement column per table and the table mus have a primary key.

Please check:
  • Columns have the same data type, same unsigned setting
  • Referred column is primary key or mandatory with an unique index
  • Data in the referring column exists in the primary key column

The Primary Key or Unique Indexes cannot contain a value two times. Same for unique indexes.
Check if the value already exist.

advice.pattern: Cannot add or update a child row: a foreign key constraint fails
advice.message:
The foreign key constraint is not respected by the new value.
This value should exist also in the primary key table.

Please use 'Use JDBC URL' tab and add this parameter to the URL: &serverTimezone=UTC;
This is an error from the latest MySQL JDBC driver which require to set the timezone on server or client.
You can also try to upload in DbSchema an older JDBC driver.

advice.pattern: Failed to open the referenced table
advice.message: Creating foreign keys require both tables to use the InnoDB engine. Check this in the options tab of the table dialog.
The referring and referred columns should use the same data type.

OpenJDK disabled TLS10 and TLS11 as unsecure. Upgrade your MySql or add 'tlsVersions=TLSv1.0' to the JDBC URL (choose Edit Manually in the URL combo).
Alternatively, edit jre/conf/security/java.security and remove TLSv1, TLSv1.1 from the line 'jdk.tls.disabledAlgorithms=...'
The Java folder is showing in the Help /About Dialog.
Choose 'Edit Manually' in the JDBC URL combo, and add 'useSSL=false' to the JDBC URL.
The database user is now allowed to write in the database. Give the user write rights or login using a different user.
